messageBody:
Hello all,

I have been learning Quickscript off and on for a few months. Unfortunately, it's one of those "spare time" things that there's rarely any spare time for.

In looking for improved PDA input methods I have run across some interesting programs that might be of use to the Quickscript/Shavian users.

First, check out Dasher. This is an innovated input method used primarily with the disabled, but it's finding all sorts of other uses. It uses a
scrolling method where letters approach from one side of the screen and move toward the other. The user aims the pointed at the desired letter,
and as the letter passes the pointer it is added to the currently forming word. Dasher learns frequently used words the more it is used, so as a
user picks letters Dasher imphasizes the letters that are most likely to come next.

The other neat thing about Dasher is that it is possible to create any language set for Dasher by creating a new xml file. Thus, Dasher could be
used as an input method for Quickscript/Shavian that doesn't required remapping the keyboard or trying to figure out which letter corresponds to
which symbol. I haven't had a chance to fiddle with this yet, and, unfortunately, it looks like it may require the character set to be supported in unicode.

Dasher is available for Windows, Linux, Pocket PC, and Mac.

http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/dasher/

Someone's got it doing Klingon, Ogham, and Runic. See the very bottom of the page.
http://www.inference.phy.cam.ac.uk/dasher/download/alphabets/ALPHABETS.html


Another interesting program for Pocket PC users is InPad. This is a replacement input method that works sort of like the block recognizer or
Grafiti on Palm devices. However, it allows the creation of customer character inputs by using a grid. The user can draw a character on the
grid, and based on which grid boxes are connected and in what order determines which character was drawn. I was working on a Quickscript character set for it, but my PDA got wiped out a while back and I haven't gone back to InPad yet.

The major negative point for InPad is that it's not free. It does have a trial version, but after twenty days or so it requires registration. InPad is also a little tricky since a lot of characters could use the same grid patterns, so it would require starting different symbols at different points in the grid just to differentiate them all.

www.inpad.net


Something to consider for the Unicode usage might be the ConScript Unicode Registry. (http://www.evertype.com/standards/csur/) This is a registry to track constructed languages and other scripts that will probably never be made into an official Unicode page. There's a Unicode area reserved for private use, and the ConScript Registry is helping people use this private area without stepping on each others' toes. We could register Quickscript here temporarily until an actual Unicode page area gets approved.

Of course, using the private use area means making new fonts that use the new unicode mappings, and then redoing those fonts, and documents created
with those fonts, later if the real Unicode mappings go through.


On an unrelated note, I'm going to toot my own horn and point everyone at the page below. I started working on some Quickscript lessons for my
own use. I have two completed, and am half way through a third one. They are helpful for me in practicing drawing the symbols and remembering the sounds. I based the lessons loosely on Read's suggestions, and I was going for a textbook style to the lessons. They're rather plain at the moment, but functional. If anyone else finds them useful please let me know, and I will post here as I complete more of them. Also, suggestions are welcome on improvements or changes that would help new students learn the script.

www.corporate-slave.com/quickscript.html


Thanks,

Edward Boudreaux
